### Description

Stuck indexing when adding more that one project folder to atom-beta
### Steps to Reproduce
1. `$ atom-beta ./<project>`
2. Atom opens - `Cmd+T`, Fuzzy window works fine
3. `$ atom-beta --add ~/<path>/<project>` - another project added to atom
4. In atom - `Cmd+T`, Fuzzy window shows:

![screen shot 2016-05-02 at 01 10 40](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2122679/14944738/a15d928a-1005-11e6-8dc7-5162cd11b85a.png)

**Note!** This steps are reproducing the bug only in `atom-beta`. In `atom` this bug appears for some other reason sometimes.

**Expected behavior:** Both projects successfully indexed and possible to open file using Fuzzy window.

**Actual behavior:** Stuck while indexing
### Versions

Atom:

```
$ atom -version
Atom    : 1.7.3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

Atom-beta:

```
$ atom-beta -version
Atom    : 1.8.0-beta3
Electron: 0.36.8
Chrome  : 47.0.2526.110
Node    : 5.1.1
```

data.title: Different comment styles
data.body:
### Description

Add ability to style different types of comments. This is useful since different comments can have different purposes. Some comments can be of the 'section' type and some can be of the 'small comment type'. Being able to style these differently is often of great help when working with code.

1. Add single-line comment ie // comment

**Actual behavior:** No difference between comment and _comment_

1.7.2

data.title: Implement silent upgrade of Atom
data.body:
I do not see any reason why Atom would not be able to update itself without requiring any user intervention. Once the application is not used (foreground) for a number of minutes it should just restart in order to install the newer version.

Our time is too precious to be wasted on manually upgrading applications, hide this boring task. Obviously that if someone wants to be in-control of that behaviour they could enable or disable this in the settings.

data.title: Feature Request: restore unsaved tabs upon restart
data.body:
### Description

Atom does not restore text entered in new (unsaved) tabs.
This is a feature request.

Related issues ([#8327](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8327), [#942](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/942)) were closed but this is still a thing in version 1.7.3
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Start Atom
2. Create a new tab
3. Type something in the tab
4. Close Atom
5. Reopen Atom
6. Text is gone

**Expected behavior:**

Unsaved tabs should be restored (sublimetext does this) even when they are not saved explicitly to a file to allow for quick jotting down of ideas or code snippets.

**Actual behavior:**

All entered text is gone.
### Versions

Atom 1.7.3
OSX 10.10.5

I had to disable "check for updates" under Help > About because Atom would download updates over a roaming connection (wifi tethererd via phone). But now I have to remember to check for updates. Wouldn't it be better if it would still check for updates but give a notification for it when one is available?

The default behaviour could still be to automatically download and install them, but instead of a checkbox with "Check for updates" I'd rather see a "Automatically download updates" option and a notification if it isn't checked.

Or maybe this is an idea for a package? I have no experience with building those for atom so... uuhm.. I'd need help with that :)

data.title: Filenames display with normalized spaces in tabs
data.body:
Opening a file with multiple spaces in the filename displays as one space.
It appears to be normalizing whitespace in the display of the filename.
For example a filename with 2 or more spaces displays in the tab as one space:
"811347  1_por.xml"
displays as 
"811347 1_por.xml"

This screenshot shows two filenames where one has multiple spaces and one that has only one space. They look identical in the tabs title.

data.title: Persist the entire state on reload
data.body:
This fixes an annoying problem that prevented the state of marker layers from being saved (i.e. selections history, bookmarks, etc.) when the window was reloaded either via `Cmd+R` in DevTools or via `Ctrl+Option+Cmd+L` in Atom.

The issue was that we were _always_ scheduling `saveState` on an idle callback: `window.onbeforeunload`, however, doesn't wait for that event before closing the window, and thus that state was never saved in those situations.

The solution is to use idle callbacks only during the critical code path (i.e. on mousedown and keydown), but save it synchronously otherwise. Saving something to IndexedDB is actually asynchronous too, but it seems like Chrome/Electron fulfills `put` requests that get executed right during `onbeforeunload`.

/cc: @atom/core

data.title: Editor hangs forever when navigating to the end of a long line
data.body:
### Description

When the cursor is at column 0 of the line after an extremely long line, and the left arrow key is pressed to move the cursor to the end of that line, Atom freezes forever.

Moreover upon relaunch, it reopens the SAME FILE to the SAME CURSOR POSITION and hangs again, meaning the user is stuck in a permanent hang-restart loop. Atom is reduced to an annoying emulator of DLL Hell.
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Set Atom to open
2. Open a 200kB XML file, encoded in UTF-16 LE, that has all its text distributed on two lines.
3. Atom opens this file with your cursor at the top left.
4. Move the cursor to column 0 of the second line.
5. Press the left arrow key.
6. Atom wraps around and then hangs forever.
### Versions

1.7.3, tested on OSX 10.11.4 and Windows 10 x64.

data.title: :checkered_flag: refactor registry and PoSH out of squirrel-update
data.body:
The first aim is to extract Windows Registry and PowerShell operations from squirrel-update: having those has dependencies, it is easier to mock them and thus squirell-update tests are simplified.

In perspective, this PR is functional to further changes addressing issue #5901. Here's why:

The need for such PR arose from another currently open one, #8780 , which combines together a refactoring and a feature improvement related to Windows right-click menu. If this current PR gets merged, then #8780 would be basically superseded, hence closed, and the actual feature improvement could be discussed and brought forward separately.

As things are now, the refactoring part in #8780 needs manual updates and conflict resolution everytime the codebase moves further in the squirrel-update area. By accepting this current PR, that would be set aside once for all.

HTH

data.title: Mouse buttons 8/9 cannot be listened to from Atom
data.body:
Most mouse devices today not made by Apple have more than two button.
To be precise, my mouse is this one: http://myego.cz/img/razer-logitech/mx518.jpg
I would love if I could use all of my buttons in Atom. Currently I tried:

document.addEventListener('mousedown', (e) => console.log(e))
